articles.headline: Justice in Taxes, Most Likely Short-Lived
articles.snippet: The average tax rate for America’s top 400 income earners rose in 2013, but tax analysts said the tax structure still overwhelmingly favors the very well-off.
articles.abstract: The average tax rate for America’s top 400 income earners rose in 2013, but tax analysts said the tax structure still overwhelmingly favors the very well-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is the party over for America’s super-rich?

articles.headline: Experts Foresee Obstacles for Both Sides in Bill Cosby Case
articles.snippet: Legal experts said the road to conviction was filled with significant hurdles, including a lack of forensic evidence related to the decade-old allegation by the woman at the center of the case.
articles.abstract: Legal experts said the road to conviction was filled with significant hurdles, including a lack of forensic evidence related to the decade-old allegation by the woman at the center of the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, as Bill Cosby and his lawyers aggressively rebutted accusations that he was a sexual predator, his defenders could point to one incontrovertible fact: He had never been charged with a crime.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: China’s Homeless Find Shelter Under McDonald’s Golden Arches
articles.snippet: In major cities across East Asia, downtrodden people with no better place to sleep have made 24-hour McDonald’s restaurants their overnight home.
articles.abstract: In major cities across East Asia, downtrodden people with no better place to sleep have made 24-hour McDonald’s restaurants their overnight home.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — He woke to the cry of the morning janitor. “Put your shoes on!” she said. “Put your shoes on!” She rattled a chair. “This isn’t your house! Sit up!”

articles.headline: U.S. Doesn’t Know How Many Foreign Visitors Overstay Visas
articles.snippet: After two decades of failed attempts to track such visitors, some officials call the visa program a critical national security weakness.
articles.abstract: After two decades of failed attempts to track such visitors, some officials call the visa program a critical national security weakness.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The question from the congressman to the Obama administration official was straightforward enough: How many foreign visitors overstay their visas every year?
